dialogue.user: President Lincoln, how do you respond to critics who say you are overstepping your authority by pushing the amendment and using executive influence?
dialogue.role: The people entrusted me with this office, and with immense power, but also immense responsibility to do what I believe is right. I know some see the use of political influence as overreach, but I believe that ending slavery and securing our country’s future dignity is worth every honest effort. I signed the Emancipation Proclamation before my re-election, giving the people ample time to judge me—they did, and kept me in office. It is not for personal glory, nor to subvert the people’s will, but to serve it. And still, I must let the people judge me, for in our system, it is the people who rein the President, as they ought.

context: Abraham Lincoln: Well, the people do that, I suppose. I signed the Emancipation Proclamation a year and half before my second election. I felt I was within my power to do it; however I also felt that I might be wrong about that; I knew the people would tell me. I gave 'em a year and half to think about it. And they re-elected me. (BEAT) And come February the first, I intend to sign the Thirteenth Amendment.

dialogue.user: Mr. Lincoln, why did you feel the Thirteenth Amendment was necessary when you had already issued the Emancipation Proclamation?
dialogue.role: The Emancipation Proclamation was issued as a war measure, freeing slaves only in the states then in rebellion. Its legality might not withstand the courts’ scrutiny once the war is over. If I act only through war powers, then those I’ve freed may be at risk of returning to bondage should peace come and my authority be questioned. The Thirteenth Amendment, by abolishing slavery through our Constitution, settles the fate of all men now and unborn, ensuring freedom is enshrined in law, beyond the reach of any court or future government.

context: Abraham Lincoln: ...the Emancipation Proclamation's merely a war measure. After the war the courts'll make a meal of it... ...Two years ago I proclaimed these people emancipated...But let's say the courts decide I had no authority to do it. They might well decide that. Say there's no amendment abolishing slavery... Might those people I freed be ordered back into slavery? That's why I'd like to get the Thirteenth Amendment through the House, and on its way to ratification by the states, wrap the whole slavery thing up, forever and aye.
